raw_text:
Berlin hails European cinema
 
 Organisers say this year's Berlin Film Festival, which opens on Thursday with period epic Man to Man, will celebrate a revitalised European cinema.
 
 Of the 21 films in competition for the Golden and Silver Bear awards, more than half are from Europe with France particularly well represented. Festival director Dieter Kosslick says this strong showing signals "a new consciousness for European films". "They're on an incredible winning streak," he told the Reuters agency. "This isn't to say there aren't any good American films," he continued. "It's just that there are more good European films."
 
 However, Mr Kosslick refused to accept that widespread opposition to the Iraq war had turned audiences against Hollywood imports. "There is no anti-American mood," he said. Some 350 films will be screened at this year's festival, with a further 300 shown at the European Film Market that runs alongside it. More than a dozen celebrities are scheduled to attend, among them Will Smith, Kevin Spacey and Keanu Reeves. But Mr Kosslick says more would be coming had the Academy Awards not been brought forward to 27 February. "I'm not worried that we won't be able to fill the red carpet with stars," he said, though he admitted the festival may be moved to January next year to avoid a similar clash. The 10-day Berlinale runs until 20 February.
llama3.2:1b: Berlin hails European cinema; this year's film festival features more than half of its entries from Europe, particularly France.
Festival director Dieter Kosslick says this indicates "a new consciousness for European films."
However, he notes there are still good American films and that widespread opposition to the Iraq war has not led audiences away from Hollywood imports.
llama3.2:3b: The Berlin Film Festival will celebrate a revitalized European cinema with more than half of the 21 films in competition coming from Europe, particularly France.
Director Dieter Kosslick attributes this success to a "new consciousness" for European films, noting that audiences are responding positively to them.
However, he denies speculation about an anti-American mood among festivalgoers, citing a strong lineup of international celebrities attending the event.

Despite strong competition from American films,  festival director Dieter Kosslick believes this is due to the increased quality of European productions.
Celebrities like Will Smith, Kevin Spacey and Keanu Reeves are scheduled to attend, though the festival may be moved to January next year to avoid a clash with the Academy Awards.

Key points from the text:

- Berlin Film Festival celebrates revitalized European cinema

- More than half of films in competition for awards are from Europe, with France particularly represented

- Director Dieter Kosslick praises a "new consciousness" for European films

- The festival will screen 350 films and have an additional 300 at the European Film Market, including celebrities like Will Smith, Kevin Spacey, and Keanu Reeves.
- More than 10 days of film screenings are planned from February 10 to February 20.

Over 300 films will be screened, including appearances by Will Smith, Kevin Spacey and Keanu Reeves.
The festival runs until February 20th with some concern over potential overlap with Academy Awards.

However, Mr Kosslick refuses to accept the uneasiness of falling opponents with Hollywood imports.
"There is no fear of anti-American sentiments," he said, noting that there were more good European films than bad.

However, Mr Kosslick remains adamant on accepting the festival's schedule and move to January next year as it has not been negatively affected by the Iraq war and the rise of American films could set the red carpet.
The 10-day Berlin Festival runs until 20 February.
